bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank R. McCoy, February 12, 1948

div1.p: Hench discusses his planned book on yellow fever and his interest in the subject. Hench questions McCoy about Wood's support of Reed's experimentation, in Cuba, and possible opposition from the Surgeon General.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank R. McCoy, February 12, 1948
div1.opener:
CC: General Kean
February 12, 1948
Major General Frank R. McCoy
1633 31st Street, N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General McCoy:
div1.p:
For several years I have been greatly interested in the story of
Walter Reed and the conquest of yellow fever. By separate post I am sending
you a reprint of a little article which I wrote on the subject.

With the help of General Jefferson R. Kean and many others, I am
writing a book on the subject. In this connection, I have visited Cuba three
times and am on my way there again.

There are still a few parts of the story that are not quite clear to
me. In reading recently Hagedorn's biography of Leonard Wood (Harpers 1931)
I find in Volume I, on page 332 the statement “Twice indeed, the investigation
(Reed's) had nearly been stopped by orders from the Surgeon General, who needed
his doctors and felt that too much time had already been wasted, but each time
Wood had intervened and saved the commission” (Ref. 23, McCoy from the S. G.,
1929).

General McCoy, I have never seen this statement elsewhere and it
interests me greatly. I have spend quite a bit of time going through the
old Army records in the Archives Building but never ran across that incident.
I am most anxious to find out more about it. I am speaking in Washington be-
fore the District of Columbia Medical Society this next Wednesday evening,
February 18 and Mrs. Hench and I will be leaving for Florida and Cuba on the
19th. Would it be possible for me to contact you the morning of the 19th,
Thursday, and call on you briefly to discuss this point? I am anxious in-
deed to find the official sources of the statement and undoubtedly you can
help me greatly. I will make my call brief. I will be staying at the
Hotel Mayflower. Would it be possible for you to drop me a note there
ahead of time, telling me whether or not it is convenient for me to call
on you on the 19th?
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
